Robust Federated Learning in a Heterogeneous Environment

Avishek Ghosh Equal contributions.   Justin Hong††footnotemark:   Dong Yin Kannan Ramchandran
Abstract

We study a recently proposed large-scale distributed learning paradigm, namely Federated Learning, where the worker machines are end users’ own devices. Statistical and computational challenges arise in Federated Learning particularly in the presence of heterogeneous data distribution (i.e., data points on different devices belong to different distributions signifying different clusters) and Byzantine machines (i.e., machines that may behave abnormally, or even exhibit arbitrary and potentially adversarial behavior). To address the aforementioned challenges, first we propose a general statistical model for this problem which takes both the cluster structure of the users and the Byzantine machines into account. Then, leveraging the statistical model, we solve the robust heterogeneous Federated Learning problem optimally; in particular our algorithm matches the lower bound on the estimation error in dimension and the number of data points. Furthermore, as a by-product, we prove statistical guarantees for an outlier-robust clustering algorithm, which can be considered as the Lloyd algorithm with robust estimation. Finally, we show via synthetic as well as real data experiments that the estimation error obtained by our proposed algorithm is significantly better than the non-Byzantine-robust algorithms; in particular, we gain at least by 53% and 33% for synthetic and real data experiments, respectively, in typical settings.

1 Introduction

Distributed computing is becoming increasingly important in many modern data-intensive applications like computer vision, natural language processing and recommendation systems. Federated Learning ([1, 2, 3]) is one recently proposed distributed computing paradigm that aims to fully utilize on-device machine intelligence—in such systems, data are stored in end users’ own devices such as mobile phones and personal computers. Many statistical and computational challenges arise in Federated Learning, due to the highly decentralized system architecture. In this paper, we aim to tackle two challenges in Federated Learning: Byzantine robustness and heterogeneous data distribution.

In Federated Learning, robustness has become one of the major concerns since individual computing units (worker machines) may exhibit abnormal behavior owing to corrupted data, faulty hardware, crashes, unreliable communication channels, stalled computation, or even malicious and coordinated attacks . It is well known that the overall performance of such a system can be arbitrarily skewed even if a single machine behaves in a Byzantine way. Hence it is necessary to develop distributed learning algorithms that are provably robust against Byzantine failures. This is considered in a few recent works, and much progress has been made (see [4, 5, 6, 7, 8]).

In practice, since worker nodes are end users’ personal devices, the issue of data heterogenity naturally arises in Federated Learning. Exploiting data heterogenity is particularly crucial in recommendation systems and personalized advertisement placement, which benefits both the users’ and the enterprises. For example, mobile phone users who read news articles may be interested in different categories of news like politics, sports or fashion; advertisement platforms might need to send different categories of ads to different groups of customers. These indicate that leveraging cluster structures among the users is of potential interest—each machine itself may not have enough data and thus we need to better utilize the similarity among the users in the same cluster. This problem has recently received attention in [9] in a non-statistical multi-task setting.

We believe that more effort is needed in this area in order to achieve better statistical guarantees and robustness against Byzantine failures. In this paper, we aim to tackle the data heterogeneity and Byzantine-robustness problems simultaneously. We propose a statistical model, along with a 333 stage algorithm that solves the aforementioned problem yielding an estimation error which is optimal in dimension and number of data points. The crux of our approach lies in analyzing a clustering algorithm in the presence of adversarial data points. In particular, we study the classical Lloyd’s algorithm augmented with robust estimation. Specifically, we show that the number of misclustered points with the robust Lloyd algorithm decays at an exponential rate when initialized properly. We now summarize the contributions of the paper.

1.1 Our contributions

We propose a general and flexible statistical model and a general algorithmic framework to address the heterogeneous Federated Learning problem in the presence of Byzantine machines. Our algorithmic framework consists of three stages: finding local solutions, performing centralized robust clustering and doing joint robust distributed optimization. The error incurred by our algorithm is optimal in several problem parameters. Furthermore, our framework allows for flexible choices of algorithms in each stage, and can be easily implemented in a modular manner.

Moreover, as a by-product, we analyze an outlier-robust clustering scheme, which may be considered as the Lloyd’s algorithm with robust estimation. The idea of robustifying the Lloyd’s algorithm is not new (e.g. see[10, 11] and the references therein) and several robust Lloyd algorithms are empirically well studied. However, to the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that analyzes and prove guarantees for such algorithms in a statistical setting, and might be of independent interest.

We validate our theoretical results via simulations on both synthetic and real world data. For synthetic experiments, using a mixture of regressions model, we find that our proposed algorithm drastically outperforms the non-Byzantine-robust algorithms. Further, using Yahoo! Learning to Rank dataset, we demonstrate that our proposed algorithm is practical, easy to implement and dominates the standard non-robust algorithms.

1.2 Related work

Distributed and Federated Learning:

Learning with a distributed computing framework has been studied extensively in various settings [12, 13, 14, 15, 16]. Since the paradigm of Federated Learning presented by [1, 3], several recent works focus on different applications of the problem, such as in deep learning [2], predicting health events from wearable devices, and detecting burglaries in smart homes [17, 18]. While [19] deals with fairness in Federated Learning, [20, 21] deal with non-iid data. A few recent works study heterogeneity under different setting in Federated Learning, for example see [9, 22, 23, 24] and the references therein. However, neither of these papers explicitly utilize the cluster structure of the problem in the presence of Byzantine machines. Also, in most cases, the objective is to learn a single optimal parameter for the whole problem, instead of learning optimal parameters for each cluster. In contrast, the MOCHA algorithm [9] considers a multi-task learning setting and forms an optimization problem with the correlation matrix of the users being a regularization term. Our work differs from MOCHA since we consider a statistical setting and the Byzantine-robustness.

Byzantine-robustness:

The robustness and security issues in distributed learning has received much attention ([25, 26]). In particular, one recent work by [27] studies the Byzantine-robust distributed learning from heterogeneous datasets. However, the basic goal of this work differs from ours, since we aim to optimize different prediction rules for different users, whereas [27] tries to find a single optimal solution.

Clustering and mixture models:

In the centralized setting, outlier-robust clustering and mixture models have been extensively studied. Robust clustering has been studied in many previous works [28, 29, 30]. One recent work [31] considers a statistical model for robust clustering, similar to ours. However, their algorithm is computationally heavy and hard to implement, whereas the robust clustering algorithm in our paper is more intuitive and straightforward to implement. Our work is also related to learning mixture models, such as mixture of experts [32] and mixture of regressions [33, 34].

2 Problem setup

We consider a standard statistical setting of empirical risk minimization (ERM). Our goal is to learn several parametric models by minimizing some (convex) loss functions defined by the data. Suppose we have m𝑚m compute nodes, α​m​(α<0.5)𝛼𝑚𝛼0.5\alpha m~{}(\alpha<0.5) of which are Byzantine nodes, i.e., nodes that are arbitrarily corrupted by some adversary. Out of the non-Byzantine compute nodes, we assume that there are K𝐾K different data distributions, 𝒟1,…,𝒟Ksubscript𝒟1…subscript𝒟𝐾\mathcal{D}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{D}_{K}, and that the (1−α)​m1𝛼𝑚(1-\alpha)m machines are partitioned into K𝐾K clusters, 𝒞1,…,𝒞Ksubscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝐾\mathcal{C}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{K}. Suppose that every node i∈𝒞k𝑖subscript𝒞𝑘i\in\mathcal{C}_{k} contains n𝑛n i.i.d. data points xi,1,…,xi,nsuperscript𝑥𝑖1…superscript𝑥𝑖𝑛x^{i,1},\ldots,x^{i,n} drawn from 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. We also assume that we have no control over the data distribution of the corrupt nodes. Let f​(w;x):𝒲→ℝ:𝑓𝑤𝑥→𝒲ℝf(w;x):\mathcal{W}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be the loss function associated with data point x𝑥x, where 𝒲⊆ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{W}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d} is the parameter space. Our goal is to find the minimizers of all the K𝐾K population risk functions. For the k𝑘k-th cluster, the minimizer is wk∗=arg⁡minw∈𝒲⁡Fk​(w)(:=𝔼x∼𝒟k​f​(w;x))subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘annotatedsubscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤assignabsentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑥subscript𝒟𝑘𝑓𝑤𝑥w^{*}_{k}=\arg\min_{w\in\mathcal{W}}F_{k}(w)(:=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}}f(w;x)).

The challenges in learning {wi∗}i=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖𝑖1𝐾\{w^{*}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} are: (i) we need a clustering scheme that work in presence of adversaries. Since, we have no control over the corrupted nodes, it is not possible to cluster all the nodes perfectly. Hence we need a robust distributed optimization algorithm. (ii) we want our algorithm to minimize uplink communication cost( [3]). Throughout, we use C,C1,.,c,c1,.C,C_{1},.,c,c_{1},. for universal constants; whose value may vary from line to line. Also, ||.||||.|| denotes ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm.

3 A modular algorithm for robust Federated Learning in heterogeneous environment

In this section, we present a modular algorithm that consists of 333 stages—(1) Compute local empirical risk minimizers (ERMs) and send them to the center machine (2) Run outlier-robust clustering algorithm on these local ERMs and (3) Run a communication-efficient, robust, distributed optimization on each cluster (Algorithm 1, also see Figure 1).

3.1 Stage I- compute ERMs

In this step, each compute node calculates the local empirical risk minimizer (ERM) associated to its risk function send them to the center machine. Since machine i𝑖i is associated with the local risk function, defined as F(i)​(w)=1n​∑j=1nf​(w,xi,j)superscript𝐹𝑖𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛𝑓𝑤superscript𝑥𝑖𝑗F^{(i)}(w)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}f(w,x^{i,j}), the local ERM, w^(i):=argminw∈𝒲​F(i)​(w)assignsuperscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptargmin𝑤𝒲superscript𝐹𝑖𝑤\hat{w}^{(i)}:=\mathrm{argmin}_{w\in\mathcal{W}}F^{(i)}(w). We assume the loss function f(.;.)f(.;.) is convex with respect to its first argument, and so the compute node can run a convex optimization program to solve for w^(i)superscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}^{(i)}.

Instead of solving the local risk function directly, the compute node can run an “online-to-batch conversion” routine. Each compute node runs an online optimization algorithm like Online Gradient Descent [35]. At iteration l𝑙l, the compute node picks wlsubscript𝑤𝑙w_{l}, and incurs a loss of f​(wl,xl)𝑓subscript𝑤𝑙subscript𝑥𝑙f(w_{l},x_{l}). After n𝑛n episodes with the sequence of functions f(.,x1),…,f(.,xn)f(.,x_{1}),\ldots,f(.,x_{n}), the compute node sets the predictor w¯(i)superscript¯𝑤𝑖\bar{w}^{(i)} as the average of the online choices w1,…,wnsubscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑛w_{1},\ldots,w_{n} made over n𝑛n instances. This predictor has similar properties like ERMs, however in case of online optimization, there is no need to store all n𝑛n data points apriori, and the entire operation is in a streaming setup.

3.2 Stage II- cluster the ERMs

The second step of the modular algorithms deals with clustering the compute nodes based on their local ERMs. All m𝑚m compute nodes send local ERMs, w^(i)superscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}^{(i)}, for i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m] 111For integer q𝑞q, [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] denotes the set of integers {1,…,q}1…𝑞\{1,\ldots,q\}. to the center machine, and the center machine runs a clustering algorithm on these data points to find K𝐾K clusters 𝒞1,…,𝒞Ksubscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝐾\mathcal{C}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{K}. Since compute nodes can be Byzantine, the clustering algorithm should be outlier-robust.

We show (in Section LABEL:sec:naive_cluster) that if the amount of data in each worker node, n𝑛n is reasonably large, a simple threshold based clustering rule is sufficient. This scheme uses the fact that the local ERMs of 222 machines belonging to a same cluster are close, whereas they are far apart for different clusters. However, if n𝑛n is small (which is pragmatic in Federated Learning), the aforementioned scheme fails to work. An alternative is to use a robust version of Lloyd algorithm (K𝐾K-means). In particular: (i) at each iteration, assign the data points to its closest center (ii) compute a robust estimate of the mean with the assigned points for each cluster and use them as new centers and (iii) iterate until convergence.

The first step is identical to that of the data point assignment of K𝐾K-means algorithm. There are a few options for robust estimation for mean. Out of them the most common estimates are geometric median [36], coordinate-wise median, and trimmed mean . Although these mean estimates are robust, the estimation error ∼dsimilar-toabsent𝑑\sim\sqrt{d} (d𝑑d being the dimension) which is prohibitive in large dimension. There is a recent line of work on robust mean estimation that adapts nicely to high dimension [37, 38]. In these results, the mean estimation error is either dimension-independent or very weakly dependent on dimension. In Section A, we analyze this clustering scheme rigorously both in moderate and high dimension.

Since we are dealing with the case where α​m𝛼𝑚\alpha m workers are corrupted, and since we do not have control over the corrupt machines, no clustering algorithm can cluster all the compute nodes correctly, and hence we need a robust optimization algorithm that takes care of the adversarially corrupt (albeit Byzantine) nodes. This is precisely done in the third stage of the modular algorithm.

3.3 Stage III- outlier-robust distributed optimization

After clustering, we run an outlier-robust distributed algorithm on each cluster. Each cluster can be thought of an instance of homogeneous distributed learning problem with possibly Byzantine machines. Hence, we can use the trimmed mean algorithm of [7] (since it has optimal statistical rate) for low to moderate dimension and the iterative filtering algorithm of [8] for high dimension. These algorithms are communication-efficient; the number of parallel iterations needed matches the standard results of gradient descent algorithm.

Comparison with an Oracle: We compare the above bound with an Oracle inequality. We assume that the oracle knows the cluster identity for all the non-Byzantine machines. Since with high probability, the modular algorithm makes no mistake in clustering the non-Byzantine machines, the bound we get perfectly matches the oracle bound.

We now move to the setting where we have no restriction on n𝑛n, and hence n𝑛n may be potentially much smaller than d𝑑d. This setting is more realistic since data arising from applications (like images and video) are high dimensional, and the amount of data in data owners’ device may be small ([1]). We start with the following assumption.

Assumption 6.

The empirical risk minimizers, {w^(i)}i=1(1−α)​msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝑤𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚\{\hat{w}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m}, corresponding to non-Byzantine machines are sampled from a mixture of K𝐾K σ𝜎\sigma-sub-gaussian distributions.

We emphasize that several learning problems satisfy Assumption 6. We now exhibit one such setting where the empirical risk minimizer is Gaussian. We assume that machine i𝑖i belongs to cluster 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k}. Recall that {xi,j}j=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑗1𝑛\{x^{i,j}\}_{j=1}^{n} denote the data points for machine i𝑖i.

Proposition 1.

Suppose the data {xi,j}j=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑗1𝑛\{x^{i,j}\}_{j=1}^{n} are sampled from a parametric class of generative model: xi,j=⟨χj,wk∗⟩+Υjsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝜒𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘subscriptΥ𝑗x^{i,j}=\langle\chi_{j},w^{*}_{k}\rangle+\Upsilon_{j} with covariate χjT∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝜒𝑗𝑇superscriptℝ𝑑\chi_{j}^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and i.i.d noise Υj∼𝒩​(0,υ2)similar-tosubscriptΥ𝑗𝒩0superscript𝜐2\Upsilon_{j}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\upsilon^{2}). In general, sub-Gaussian distributions form a huge class, including all bounded distributions. For non-Byzantine machines, we assume the observation model: w^(i)=θzi+τisuperscript^𝑤𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖\hat{w}^{(i)}=\theta_{z_{i}}+\tau_{i} where {zi}i=1(1−α)​m∈[K]superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚delimited-[]𝐾\{z_{i}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m}\in[K] are unknown labels and {θi}i=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑖1𝐾\{\theta_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} are the unknown means of the sub-gaussian distribution. We denote {τi}i=1(1−α)​msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚\{\tau_{i}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m} as independent and zero mean sub-gaussian noise with parameter σ𝜎\sigma. We propose and analyze a robust clustering algorithm presented in Algorithm 2. At iteration s𝑠s, let zi(s)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑠z_{i}^{(s)} be the label of the i𝑖i-th data point, and θ^g(s)subscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑠𝑔\hat{\theta}^{(s)}_{g} for g∈[K]𝑔delimited-[]𝐾g\in[K] be the estimate of the centers.

In Algorithm 2, we retain the nearest neighbor assignment of the Lloyd algorithm but change the sample mean estimate to a robust mean estimate using geometric median-based trimming.

We now introduce a few new notations. Let Δ:=ming≠h∈[K]⁡‖θg−θh‖assignΔsubscript𝑔ℎdelimited-[]𝐾normsubscript𝜃𝑔subscript𝜃ℎ\Delta:=\min_{g\neq h\in[K]}\|\theta_{g}-\theta_{h}\| denote the minimum separation between clusters. The worst case error in the centers are determined by Λs=maxh∈[K]⁡‖θ^h(s)−θh‖/ΔsubscriptΛ𝑠subscriptℎdelimited-[]𝐾normsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃ℎ𝑠subscript𝜃ℎΔ\Lambda_{s}=\max_{h\in[K]}\|\hat{\theta}_{h}^{(s)}-\theta_{h}\|/\Delta. In Section 5.2 and A.3 (of the supplementary material), these quantities are formally defined along with the initialization condition, Λ0subscriptΛ0\Lambda_{0}.

Recall that |𝒞i|=Misubscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑀𝑖|\mathcal{C}_{i}|=M_{i} and note that from Theorem 7, when Algorithm 2 is run for a constant S𝑆S number of iterations, we get GS≤ϱsubscript𝐺𝑆italic-ϱG_{S}\leq\varrho with high probability. Also, let α~i=(ϱ​Mi+α​mMi+α​m)subscript~𝛼𝑖italic-ϱsubscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚\tilde{\alpha}_{i}=\left(\frac{\varrho M_{i}+\alpha m}{M_{i}+\alpha m}\right). Since GSsubscript𝐺𝑆G_{S} denotes fraction of non-Byzantine machines that are misclustered, α~isubscript~𝛼𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i} denotes the worst case fraction of Byzantine machines in cluster i𝑖i. We assume maxi∈[K]⁡α~i<12subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝐾subscript~𝛼𝑖12\max_{i\in[K]}\tilde{\alpha}_{i}<\frac{1}{2}.

Theorem 2.

Suppose Assumptions 2, 3, 4 and 6 hold along with the separation and initialization conditions (Assumptions 8 of Section 5). Furthermore, suppose Algorithm 1 is run with “Trimmed K𝐾K means” (Algorithm 2) for stage II for a constant S𝑆S iterations; and the trimmed mean algorithm (of [7]) for stage III for T𝑇T iterations with constant step-size of 1/L11subscript𝐿11/L_{1}. Then, provided T≥𝒪~​(L1+λFλF)𝑇~𝒪subscript𝐿1subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆𝐹T\geq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{L_{1}+\lambda_{F}}{\lambda_{F}}), for all i∈[K]𝑖delimited-[]𝐾i\in[K], we have

‖w^i−wi∗‖≤𝒪~​(α~i​dn+dn​Mi).normsubscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖~𝒪subscript~𝛼𝑖𝑑𝑛𝑑𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖\displaystyle\|\hat{w}_{i}-w^{*}_{i}\|\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\tilde{\alpha}_{i}d}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{d}{\sqrt{nM_{i}}}\right).

with probability at least 1−m−10−𝒪​(d(1+n​Mi)d)1superscript𝑚10𝒪𝑑superscript1𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖𝑑1-m^{-10}-\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{d}{(1+nM_{i})^{d}}\right).

Remark 3.

Like before, we can remove Assumption 2 and obtain guarantee on Fi(.)F_{i}(.) for all i∈[K]𝑖delimited-[]𝐾i\in[K].

Comparison with the oracle: Recall that the oracle knows the cluster labels of all the non-Byzantine machines. Hence, the worst case fraction of Byzantine machines will be α^i=α​mMi+α​msubscript^𝛼𝑖𝛼𝑚subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚\hat{\alpha}_{i}=\frac{\alpha m}{M_{i}+\alpha m}. Consequently, we observe that the obliviousness of the clustering identity hurts by a factor of (α~i−α^i)​dn=(ϱ​MiMi+α​m)​dnsubscript~𝛼𝑖subscript^𝛼𝑖𝑑𝑛italic-ϱsubscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚𝑑𝑛(\tilde{\alpha}_{i}-\hat{\alpha}_{i})\frac{d}{\sqrt{n}}=(\frac{\varrho M_{i}}{M_{i}+\alpha m})\frac{d}{\sqrt{n}} in the precision of learning weight wi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖w^{*}_{i}. A few remarks are in order.

Remark 4.

As seen in Section B.2, if K=2𝐾2K=2 and θ1=−θ2subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\theta_{1}=-\theta_{2}, we show that ϱ=0italic-ϱ0\varrho=0 if “Trimmed K𝐾K means” is run for at least 3​log⁡m3𝑚3\log m iterations provided Δσ≥C​log⁡mΔ𝜎𝐶𝑚\frac{\Delta}{\sigma}\geq C\sqrt{\log m}. Hence our precision bound matches perfectly with the oracle bound.

Remark 5.

The dependence on d𝑑d can be improved if iterative filtering algorithm ([8]) is used in stage III of the modular algorithm. We get ‖w^i−wi∗‖≤𝒪~​(α~in+dn​Mi)normsubscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖~𝒪subscript~𝛼𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖\|\hat{w}_{i}-w^{*}_{i}\|\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\tilde{\alpha}_{i}}}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\sqrt{nM_{i}}}\right) with high probability.

4.1 Oracle optimality

In the presence of the oracle, our problem decomposes to K𝐾K homogeneous ones. We study the dependence of the estimation error of Theorem 2 on n,d,α𝑛𝑑𝛼n,d,\alpha, and Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i} under such a setting.

Dependence on (n,Mi,α)𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼(n,M_{i},\alpha):

We compare our results with the lower bounds presented in [7, Observation 1] assuming d𝑑d is constant. It is immediate that the dependence on n𝑛n and Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i} is optimal. To see the dependence on α𝛼\alpha, we first consider the special case of K=2𝐾2K=2 with centers θ1=−θ2subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\theta_{1}=-\theta_{2}. Here α~i=α​mMi+α​msubscript~𝛼𝑖𝛼𝑚subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚\tilde{\alpha}_{i}=\frac{\alpha m}{M_{i}+\alpha m}. Typically, Mi≫α​mmuch-greater-thansubscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚M_{i}\gg\alpha m and hence α~i≈α​mMisubscript~𝛼𝑖𝛼𝑚subscript𝑀𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i}\approx\frac{\alpha m}{M_{i}}. Comparing with the bound in [7, Observation 1], the dependence on α𝛼\alpha is near optimal in this case. However for a K𝐾K cluster setting, α~isubscript~𝛼𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i} may not be linear in α𝛼\alpha in general (since ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho is not proportional to α~isubscript~𝛼𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i}).

Dependence on dimension d𝑑d:

In this setting, instead of running the trimmed mean algorithm as the distributed optimization subroutine, we run the iterative filtering algorithm of [8], and as shown in Remark 3, the dependence on d𝑑d when compared with the lower bound of [7, Observation 1] is optimal. Note that in this case, the dependence on α~isubscript~𝛼𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i} becomes sub-optimal.

5 Robust clustering

In Stage II of the modular algorithm, we cluster the local ERMs, w^(i)superscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}^{(i)} in the presence of Byzantine machines. To ease notation, we write yi=w^(i)subscript𝑦𝑖superscript^𝑤𝑖y_{i}=\hat{w}^{(i)}. Recall that for non Byzantine data-points, we have yi=θzi+τisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖y_{i}=\theta_{z_{i}}+\tau_{i}, with unknown labels {zi}i=1(1−α)​m∈[K]superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚delimited-[]𝐾\{z_{i}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m}\in[K], unknown centers {θi}i=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑖1𝐾\{\theta_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} and σ𝜎\sigma sub-Gaussian noise {τi}i=1(1−α)​msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚\{\tau_{i}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m}. For Byzantine data points yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is arbitrary. It is worth mentioning here that the classical Lloyd can be arbitrarily bad since the adversary may put the data points far away, thus causing the sample mean-based subroutine of the algorithm to fail. As a performance measure, we define the fraction of misclustered non-Byzantine data points at iteration s𝑠s as, As=1(1−α)​m​∑i∈ℳI​{zi(s)≠zi}subscript𝐴𝑠11𝛼𝑚subscript𝑖ℳ𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑠subscript𝑧𝑖A_{s}=\frac{1}{(1-\alpha)m}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{M}}I\{z_{i}^{(s)}\neq z_{i}\}, where ℳℳ\mathcal{M} denotes the set of non-Byzantine data points with |ℳ|=(1−α)​mℳ1𝛼𝑚|\mathcal{M}|=(1-\alpha)m. We first concentrate the special case where K=2𝐾2K=2 with centers θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} and −θ∗superscript𝜃-\theta^{*}, and hence yi=zi​θ∗+τisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖superscript𝜃subscript𝜏𝑖y_{i}=z_{i}\theta^{*}+\tau_{i}. With slight abuse in notation, the labels are zi∈{−1,+1}subscript𝑧𝑖11z_{i}\in\{-1,+1\} and hence, zi​yi=θ∗+zi​τi=θ∗+ξisubscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜃subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖superscript𝜃subscript𝜉𝑖z_{i}y_{i}=\theta^{*}+z_{i}\tau_{i}=\theta^{*}+\xi_{i}, where ξi∼𝒩​(0,σ2​Id)similar-tosubscript𝜉𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscript𝐼𝑑\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}I_{d}). This can be thought of estimating θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} from samples zi​yisubscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖z_{i}y_{i}.

5.3 Robust clustering in high dimension

In Sections 5.1 and 5.2, we see that the tolerable fraction of adversarial data-points decays fast with d𝑑d, which makes Algorithm 2 unsuitable for large d𝑑d. Here we analyze the symmetric 222-cluster setting only. However given LABEL:lem:ini, our analysis can be extended to general K𝐾K cluster setting. We adapt a slightly different observation model: {yi}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑚\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m} are drawn i.i.d from the following Huber contamination model: with probability 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha, yi=νi​(θ∗+τi)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜈𝑖superscript𝜃subscript𝜏𝑖y_{i}=\nu_{i}(\theta^{*}+\tau_{i}), where νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i} is a Rademacher random variable and τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} is a ζ𝜁\zeta-sub-Gaussian random vector with zero mean, and is independent of νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i}; with probability α𝛼\alpha, yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is drawn from an arbitrary distribution. We assume that the maximum eigenvalue of the covariance matrix of τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} is bounded. More specifically, we let σ~2:=λmax​(𝔼​[τi​τi⊤])assignsuperscript~𝜎2subscript𝜆𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖top\tilde{\sigma}^{2}:=\lambda_{\max}(\mathbb{E}[\tau_{i}\tau_{i}^{\top}]). We denote the distribution of y𝑦y and τ𝜏\tau by 𝒟ysubscript𝒟𝑦\mathcal{D}_{y} and 𝒟τsubscript𝒟𝜏\mathcal{D}_{\tau}, respectively. Intuitively, with probability 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha, yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is an inlier, i.e., drawn from a mixture of two symmetric distributions, and with probability α𝛼\alpha, yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is an outlier. The goal is to estimate θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} and find the correct labels (i.e., νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i}) of the inliers. We propose Algorithm 3 where the total number of data points m𝑚m is an integer multiple of the number of iterations T𝑇T, and the algorithm uses the Iterative Filtering algorithm [40, 41, 42], denoted by 𝖨𝗍𝖾𝗋𝖥𝗂𝗅𝗍𝖾𝗋𝖨𝗍𝖾𝗋𝖥𝗂𝗅𝗍𝖾𝗋\mathsf{IterFilter} as a subroutine. The intuition of the iterative filtering algorithm is to use higher order statistics, such as the sample covariance to iteratively remove outliers.

The convergence guarantee of the algorithm is in Theorem 5. We start with the following assumption:

Assumption 9.

We assume: (a) (Initialization) ‖θ^(0)−θ∗‖2≤12​‖θ∗‖subscriptnormsuperscript^𝜃0superscript𝜃212normsuperscript𝜃\|\hat{\theta}^{(0)}-\theta^{*}\|_{2}\leq\frac{1}{2}\|\theta^{*}\| (b) (SNR) ‖θ∗‖/ζ≥C1normsuperscript𝜃𝜁subscript𝐶1\|\theta^{*}\|/\zeta\geq C_{1} and (c) (Sample complexity) m≥C2α(d+1αlog(1ηlog(1β))log(1β)m\geq\frac{C_{2}}{\alpha}(d+\frac{1}{\alpha}\log(\frac{1}{\eta}\log(\frac{1}{\beta}))\log(\frac{1}{\beta}).

We emphasize that the SNR requirement is standard and the initialization condition is slightly stronger than a random guess. Armed with the above assumption, we have the following result.

Theorem 5.

Suppose that α≤1/16𝛼116\alpha\leq 1/16, σ~/ζ≤C~𝜎𝜁𝐶\tilde{\sigma}/\zeta\leq C, and let β:=3​α+8​exp⁡(−‖θ∗‖2/2​ζ2)assign𝛽3𝛼8superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃22superscript𝜁2\beta:=3\alpha+8\exp(-\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}/2\zeta^{2}). With Assumption 9 and running Algorithm 3 for T=Θ​(log⁡(1/β))𝑇Θ1𝛽T=\Theta(\log(1/\beta)) iterations, with probability at least 1−η1𝜂1-\eta, we have

‖θ^(T)−θ∗‖2≤C3​(σ~+ζ)​(α+exp⁡(−‖θ∗‖2/4​ζ2)),andsubscriptnormsuperscript^𝜃𝑇superscript𝜃2subscript𝐶3~𝜎𝜁𝛼superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃24superscript𝜁2and\displaystyle\|\hat{\theta}^{(T)}-\theta^{*}\|_{2}\leq C_{3}(\tilde{\sigma}+\zeta)(\sqrt{\alpha}+\exp(-\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}/4\zeta^{2})),\,\,\,\,\,\text{and}
ℙ​{argminν^∈{−1,1}‖ν^​y−θ^(T)∥22≠ν∣y​ is inlier}≤C4​(α+exp⁡(−‖θ∗‖2/2​ζ2)).ℙconditional-setsubscriptargmin^𝜈11^𝜈𝑦evaluated-atsuperscript^𝜃𝑇22conditional𝜈𝑦 is inliersubscript𝐶4𝛼superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃22superscript𝜁2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathrm{argmin}_{\hat{\nu}\in\{-1,1\}}\|\hat{\nu}y-\hat{\theta}^{(T)}\|_{2}^{2}\neq\nu\mid y\text{ is inlier}\right\}\leq C_{4}(\alpha+\exp(-\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}/2\zeta^{2})).

Note that the tolerable level of α𝛼\alpha has no dependence on dimension, which is an improvement over Theorem 3.

6 Experiments

We perform extensive experiments on synthetic and real data and compare the performance of our algorithm to several non-robust clustering and/or optimization-based algorithms.

6.1 Synthetic data

For synthetic experiments, we use a mixture of linear regressions model. For each cluster, a d𝑑d dimensional regression coefficient vector, {wi∗}i=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖𝑖1𝐾\{w^{*}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K}, is generated element-wise by a B​e​r​n​o​u​l​l​i​(12)𝐵𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖12Bernoulli(\frac{1}{2}) distribution. Then ⌊(1−α)​m⌋1𝛼𝑚\lfloor(1-\alpha)m\rfloor machines are uniformly assigned to the K𝐾K clusters, and ⌈α​m⌉𝛼𝑚\lceil\alpha m\rceil machines are considered adversarial machines. For each good machine, j𝑗j (belonging to cluster, i𝑖i), n𝑛n data points are generated independently according to: xj,l=χlT​wi∗+τlsuperscript𝑥𝑗𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜒𝑙𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜏𝑙x^{j,l}=\mathbf{\chi}_{l}^{T}w_{i}^{*}+\tau_{l}, for all l∈[n]𝑙delimited-[]𝑛l\in[n], where χl∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-tosubscript𝜒𝑙𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑\mathbf{\chi}_{l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) and τl∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosubscript𝜏𝑙𝒩0superscript𝜎2\tau_{l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}). For adversarial machines, the regression coefficients are sampled from 3∗B​e​r​n​o​u​l​l​i​(12)3𝐵𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖123*Bernoulli(\frac{1}{2}), resulting in outliers. We initialize the cluster assignments with 606060 percent correct assignments for the good machines. We test the performance of Lloyd (K𝐾K-means), Trimmed K𝐾K-means (Algorithm 2) and K𝐾K-geomedians (where the sample mean step of Lloyd is replaced by geometric median; note that this is Algorithm 2 excluding the trimming step). We set K=5𝐾5K=5 and m=100𝑚100m=100. In Figure 2(a), we see that the fraction of misclustered points (which we call misclustering rate) indeed diminishes with iteration at a fast rate which validates Theorem 4, whereas for K𝐾K-means, it converges to a misclustering rate of 0.40.40.4.

We compare our algorithm consisting of robust clustering (using Trimmed K𝐾K-means or K𝐾K-geomedians) and robust distributed optimization with algorithms without robust subroutines in the clustering or the optimization step. In particular we use the classical K𝐾K-means as a non robust clustering, and a naive sample averaging-based scheme (instead of robust trimmed mean-based scheme by [7]) as a non-robust, distributed algorithm. Also, in the robust optimization stage, we compare with a robust version of the Federated Averaging algorithm of [1] with 555 iterations of gradient descent in each worker node before the global model gets updated (by taking the trimmed mean of the local models in the worker nodes).

We first observe that the estimation error (maxi∈[K]⁡‖w^i−wi∗‖/dsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝐾normsubscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖𝑑\max_{i\in[K]}\|\hat{w}_{i}-w^{*}_{i}\|/\sqrt{d}) for non-robust clustering schemes (KM in Figure 2(b)) is ≥53%absentpercent53\geq 53\% higher than that using Trimmed K𝐾K-means (TKM) and K𝐾K-geomedians (KGM). Furthermore, trimmed mean-based distributed optimization (TM) strictly outperforms the sample mean-based (SM) optimization routine by ≥29%absentpercent29\geq 29\% even with robust clustering. Federated averaging (FA) does orders of magnitude worse in estimation, likely due to the poor gradient updates provided by individual machines. Hence matching our theoretical intuition, robust clustering and robust optimization have the best performance in the presence of adversaries.

6.2 Yahoo! Learning to Rank dataset

The performance of the modular algorithm is evaluated on the Yahoo Learning to Rank dataset [43]. We use the set2.test.txt file for our experiment. We choose to treat the data as unsupervised, ignoring the labels for this simulation. Starting with 103174103174103174 queries and 595595595 features, we adopt the following thresholding rule: we draw an edge between the queries with ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance less than γ𝛾\gamma (which we optimize at 3.4153.4153.415). We then run a tree-search algorithm to detect the connected graphs which produce our true cluster assignments. Small groups are removed from the dataset. This results in 444 large clusters. Next, we take the mean of the features in each cluster to obtain w1∗,…,w4∗subscriptsuperscript𝑤1…subscriptsuperscript𝑤4w^{*}_{1},\ldots,w^{*}_{4}. The data points in each cluster is then split randomly in batches of 505050 (hence, n=50𝑛50n=50). In addition, respecting α=0.3𝛼0.3\alpha=0.3, 808080 adversarial splits are incorporated via sampling 505050 points randomly from the unused data and adding a B​e​r​n​o​u​l​l​i​(12)−0.5𝐵𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖120.5Bernoulli(\frac{1}{2})-0.5 vector to the ERM. Note, we synthetically perturb the data points primarily since it is hard to find datasets with explicit adversaries. We then compute the mean in each split (these can be thought analogous to local ERMs), and perform clustering on them using K𝐾K-means, Trimmed K𝐾K-means, and K𝐾K-geomedians algorithms with fully random initialization. Then, we use trimmed mean, sample mean, or Federated Averaging optimization to estimate the w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} on each of the cluster assignment estimates with mean squared loss.

The results of the real data experiments are shown in Fig 2(c). We see that Trimmed K𝐾K-means in conjunction with trimmed mean optimization outperforms the other methods with an estimation error of 0.1250.1250.125. This algorithm is easy to implement and learns the optimal weights efficiently. On the other hand, the estimation error of K𝐾K-means algorithm with sample mean optimization is 0.2560.2560.256, which is relatively two times worse than the robust algorithms. Also, Trimmed K𝐾K-means and K𝐾K-geomedians have similar final estimation error, which further confirms that trimming step after computing the geometric median may be redundant. Thus, we once again emphasize that our robust algorithm performs better than standard non-robust algorithms.

7 Conclusion and future work

We tackle the problem of robust Federated Learning in a heterogeneous environment. We propose a 333-step modular solution to the problem. For the second step, we analyze the classical Lloyd algorithm with a robust subroutine. Weakening the sub-Gaussian assumption along with a better initialization scheme are kept as our future endeavors.

A.4.3 Proof of final results

By Assumption 8, Lemma 1 parallels Lemma A.6 in [45] with an additional term on the order of a constant, c𝑐c, where α′≤cdsuperscript𝛼′𝑐𝑑\alpha^{\prime}\leq\frac{c}{\sqrt{d}}. Setting ϵ=12ritalic-ϵ12𝑟\epsilon=\frac{12}{\sqrt{r}}, C1≥500subscript𝐶1500C_{1}\geq 500, and under the assumption that r1≥160​ksubscript𝑟1160𝑘r_{1}\geq 160\sqrt{k} we can characterize δ𝛿\delta. For example, with 2​C​σΔ≤142𝐶𝜎Δ14\frac{2C\sigma}{\Delta}\leq\frac{1}{4}, δ=12𝛿12\delta=\frac{1}{2} suffices to guarantee Gs𝒰≤0.35superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑠𝒰0.35G_{s}^{\mathcal{U}}\leq 0.35 and Λs≤12−c2subscriptΛ𝑠12𝑐2\Lambda_{s}\leq\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{2} for all s𝑠s. Thus, given an analogous recursive relationship between the two lemmas, we know the conditions for the lemmas will hold for any step s𝑠s as long as

Λ0≤12−4r1−δ​csubscriptΛ0124subscript𝑟1𝛿𝑐\displaystyle\Lambda_{0}\leq\frac{1}{2}-\frac{4}{\sqrt{r_{1}}}-\delta c

or equivalently,

Error floor

A.5 High dimension: proof of Theorem 5

For the t𝑡t-th iteration, suppose that yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is a good data point with label νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i}. Since ν^i(t)=argminν∈{−1,1}​‖ν​yi−θ^(t−1)‖22superscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡𝜈11argminsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝜈subscript𝑦𝑖superscript^𝜃𝑡122\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}=\underset{\nu\in\{-1,1\}}{\mathrm{argmin}}\|\nu y_{i}-\hat{\theta}^{(t-1)}\|_{2}^{2}, we have I​{ν^i(t)≠νi}=I​{⟨θ∗+τi,θ^(t−1)⟩≤0}𝐼superscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡subscript𝜈𝑖𝐼superscript𝜃subscript𝜏𝑖superscript^𝜃𝑡10I\{\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}\neq\nu_{i}\}=I\{\langle\theta^{*}+\tau_{i},\hat{\theta}^{(t-1)}\rangle\leq 0\}. Define the following probability

At:=ℙτ∼𝒟τ​{⟨θ∗+τ,θ^(t−1)⟩≤0}.assignsubscript𝐴𝑡subscriptℙsimilar-to𝜏subscript𝒟𝜏superscript𝜃𝜏superscript^𝜃𝑡10A_{t}:=\mathbb{P}_{\tau\sim\mathcal{D}_{\tau}}\left\{\langle\theta^{*}+\tau,\hat{\theta}^{(t-1)}\rangle\leq 0\right\}. (11)

We start by analyzing A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}. When t=1𝑡1t=1, since τ𝜏\tau is ζ𝜁\zeta-sub-Gaussian, we have

A1=ℙ​{⟨τ,θ^(0)⟩≤−⟨θ∗,θ^(0)⟩}≤exp⁡(−⟨θ∗,θ^(0)⟩22​ζ2​‖θ^(0)‖22).subscript𝐴1ℙ𝜏superscript^𝜃0superscript𝜃superscript^𝜃0superscriptsuperscript𝜃superscript^𝜃022superscript𝜁2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^𝜃022A_{1}=\mathbb{P}\left\{\langle\tau,\hat{\theta}^{(0)}\rangle\leq-\langle\theta^{*},\hat{\theta}^{(0)}\rangle\right\}\leq\exp\left(-\frac{\langle\theta^{*},\hat{\theta}^{(0)}\rangle^{2}}{2\zeta^{2}\|\hat{\theta}^{(0)}\|_{2}^{2}}\right).

By simple algebra, one can check that for any two vectors θ𝜃\theta and θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}, we have

⟨θ,θ^‖θ^‖2⟩2≥‖θ‖22−‖θ−θ^‖22.superscript𝜃^𝜃subscriptnorm^𝜃22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃^𝜃22\langle\theta,\frac{\hat{\theta}}{\|\hat{\theta}\|_{2}}\rangle^{2}\geq\|\theta\|_{2}^{2}-\|\theta-\hat{\theta}\|_{2}^{2}. (12)

Combining with initialization of Assumption 9 we have

A1≤exp⁡(−38​ζ2​‖θ∗‖22)subscript𝐴138superscript𝜁2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝜃22A_{1}\leq\exp(-\frac{3}{8\zeta^{2}}\|\theta^{*}\|_{2}^{2}) (13)

Due to the SNR condition of Assumption 9, we know that A1≤116subscript𝐴1116A_{1}\leq\frac{1}{16}. For simplicity, let n0=nTsubscript𝑛0𝑛𝑇n_{0}=\frac{n}{T} denote the number of data points used in each iteration. Thus the data points used in the t𝑡t-th iteration are y(t−1)​n0+1,y(t−1)​n0+2,…,yt​n0subscript𝑦𝑡1subscript𝑛01subscript𝑦𝑡1subscript𝑛02…subscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝑛0y_{(t-1)n_{0}+1},y_{(t-1)n_{0}+2},\ldots,y_{tn_{0}}. We use induction to prove the following result: for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, suppose that n0≥1α​(d+1α​log⁡(2/δ))subscript𝑛01𝛼𝑑1𝛼2𝛿n_{0}\geq\frac{1}{\alpha}(d+\frac{1}{\alpha}\log(2/\delta)), then, with probability at least 1−2​t​δ12𝑡𝛿1-2t\delta over the data points used in the first t𝑡t iterations, we have

At+1≤18​(At+3​α)+exp⁡(−‖θ∗‖222​ζ2)≤116.subscript𝐴𝑡118subscript𝐴𝑡3𝛼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝜃222superscript𝜁2116A_{t+1}\leq\frac{1}{8}(A_{t}+3\alpha)+\exp\left(-\frac{\|\theta^{*}\|_{2}^{2}}{2\zeta^{2}}\right)\leq\frac{1}{16}. (14)

Suppose that (14) holds for t−1𝑡1t-1, then we consider the t𝑡t-th iteration. We partition the n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} data points used in the t𝑡t-th iteration into three parts: Nt,0subscript𝑁𝑡0N_{t,0} data points which are inliers and have correct estimated labels (i.e., ν^i(t)=νisuperscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡subscript𝜈𝑖\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}=\nu_{i}); Nt,1subscript𝑁𝑡1N_{t,1} data points which are inliers and the estimated labels are wrong; Nt,2subscript𝑁𝑡2N_{t,2} data points which are outliers.

According to our contamination model and Hoeffding’s inequality, we have

ℙ​{Nt,2≥2​α​n0}≤exp⁡(−2​α2​n0).ℙsubscript𝑁𝑡22𝛼subscript𝑛02superscript𝛼2subscript𝑛0\mathbb{P}\left\{N_{t,2}\geq 2\alpha n_{0}\right\}\leq\exp(-2\alpha^{2}n_{0}). (15)

Conditioned on all the previous iterations and the fact that there are Nt,2subscript𝑁𝑡2N_{t,2} outliers, we can use Hoeffding’s inequality to bound Nt,1subscript𝑁𝑡1N_{t,1}:

ℙ​{Nt,1≥(At+α)​(n0−Nt,2)∣Nt,2}≤exp⁡(−2​α2​(n0−Nt,2)).ℙconditional-setsubscript𝑁𝑡1subscript𝐴𝑡𝛼subscript𝑛0subscript𝑁𝑡2subscript𝑁𝑡22superscript𝛼2subscript𝑛0subscript𝑁𝑡2\mathbb{P}\left\{N_{t,1}\geq(A_{t}+\alpha)(n_{0}-N_{t,2})\mid N_{t,2}\right\}\leq\exp(-2\alpha^{2}(n_{0}-N_{t,2})). (16)

Therefore, with probability at least 1−2​exp⁡(−α2​n0)12superscript𝛼2subscript𝑛01-2\exp(-\alpha^{2}n_{0}), we have

Nt,0≥(1−(At+3​α))​n0.subscript𝑁𝑡01subscript𝐴𝑡3𝛼subscript𝑛0N_{t,0}\geq(1-(A_{t}+3\alpha))n_{0}. (17)

This implies that if n0≥1α2​log⁡(2/δ)subscript𝑛01superscript𝛼22𝛿n_{0}\geq\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}\log(2/\delta), then with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, (17) holds.

The next step in the algorithm is to use the iterative filtering algorithm subroutine to conduct a robust mean estimation of θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}. To this end, we first construct n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} inliers: for every i=(t−1)​n0+1,(t−1)​n0+2,…,t​n0𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑛01𝑡1subscript𝑛02…𝑡subscript𝑛0i=(t-1)n_{0}+1,(t-1)n_{0}+2,\ldots,tn_{0}, if yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is an inlier, we let y~i:=νi​yiassignsubscript~𝑦𝑖subscript𝜈𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\tilde{y}_{i}:=\nu_{i}y_{i}; if yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is an outlier, we draw τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} from 𝒟τsubscript𝒟𝜏\mathcal{D}_{\tau} independently from all other data points, and let y~i:=θ∗+τiassignsubscript~𝑦𝑖superscript𝜃subscript𝜏𝑖\tilde{y}_{i}:=\theta^{*}+\tau_{i}. Here we note that all the new data points y~isubscript~𝑦𝑖\tilde{y}_{i} (with yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} being outliers) are virtual, i.e., they are only used for the analysis purpose.

Now we have n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} virtual data points y~isubscript~𝑦𝑖\tilde{y}_{i}, i=(t−1)​n0+1,(t−1)​n0+2,…,t​n0𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑛01𝑡1subscript𝑛02…𝑡subscript𝑛0i=(t-1)n_{0}+1,(t-1)n_{0}+2,\ldots,tn_{0} drawn from the inlier distribution with mean θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}. In the algorithm implementation, we have ν^i(t)​yisuperscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑦𝑖\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}y_{i}, i=(t−1)​n0+1,(t−1)​n0+2,…,t​n0𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑛01𝑡1subscript𝑛02…𝑡subscript𝑛0i=(t-1)n_{0}+1,(t-1)n_{0}+2,\ldots,tn_{0}. In fact, if yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is an inlier and has correct label, we have y~i=ν^i(t)​yisubscript~𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑦𝑖\tilde{y}_{i}=\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}y_{i}. Thus, the set of data points used in the algorithm {ν^i(t)​yi}superscriptsubscript^𝜈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑦𝑖\{\hat{\nu}_{i}^{(t)}y_{i}\} can be considered as a corrupted sample from {y~i}subscript~𝑦𝑖\{\tilde{y}_{i}\}. Conditioned on the event in (17), we know that with probability at least 1−2​exp⁡(−α2​n0)12superscript𝛼2subscript𝑛01-2\exp(-\alpha^{2}n_{0}), the fraction of corrupted data (including outliers and inliers with wrong labels) is at most At+3​αsubscript𝐴𝑡3𝛼A_{t}+3\alpha. According to [41, 42], the following lemma holds deterministically.

Thus, we have proved (14). The final results can be obtained by iterating (14).

Appendix B Guarantees of stage I and III of the modular algorithm

B.1 Guarantees for stage-I:

B.1.1 ERM computation

We now show closeness guarantees of the ERMs, w^(i)superscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}^{(i)} to its true risk minimizer, wk∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}^{*} for some k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]. The closeness results will be required for the provable guarantees of the threshold based clustering algorithm described in Section LABEL:sec:naive_cluster.

Suppose machine i∈𝒞k𝑖subscript𝒞𝑘i\in\mathcal{C}_{k}. The goal is to prove an upper bound on ‖w(i)−wk∗‖normsuperscript𝑤𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘\|w^{(i)}-w^{*}_{k}\|. We now present the result for completeness.

Theorem 6.

[46] Under Assumptions 1, 2 and 3, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we have

Fk​(w^(i))−F​(wk∗)≤𝒪​(G12​L1​log⁡(1/δ)λ2​n)subscript𝐹𝑘superscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝒪superscriptsubscript𝐺12subscript𝐿11𝛿superscript𝜆2𝑛\displaystyle F_{k}(\hat{w}^{(i)})-F(w_{k}^{*})\leq\mathcal{O}(\frac{G_{1}^{2}L_{1}\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda^{2}n})

Using strong convexity (Assumption 2), with probability exceeding 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we obtain

‖w^(i)−wk∗‖2≤𝒪​(G12​L1​log⁡(1/δ)λ3​n).superscriptnormsuperscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘2𝒪superscriptsubscript𝐺12subscript𝐿11𝛿superscript𝜆3𝑛\displaystyle\|\hat{w}^{(i)}-w^{*}_{k}\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(\frac{G_{1}^{2}L_{1}\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda^{3}n}).

B.1.2 Online-to-batch conversion

Here the i𝑖i-th compute node runs an online-to-batch conversion routine to obtain w¯(i)superscript¯𝑤𝑖\bar{w}^{(i)}. Suppose the loss function f(w,.)f(w,.) is convex and G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} Lipschitz with respect to w𝑤w, and w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in\mathcal{W} is bounded by D1subscript𝐷1D_{1}. [46] along with Assuption 2 shows that, with probability greater than or equal to 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we have

w¯(i)−wk∗2≤𝒪​(D12​G12​log⁡(1/δ)λ​n).superscript¯𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘2𝒪superscriptsubscript𝐷12superscriptsubscript𝐺121𝛿𝜆𝑛\displaystyle{\bar{w}^{(i)}-w^{*}_{k}}^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(\frac{D_{1}^{2}G_{1}^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda n}).

From the above results, computing the ERM directly and performing an online optimization over n𝑛n episodes are order-wise identical. All the closeness results for ERMs holds only for non-Byzantine machines.

B.2 Stage III-robust distributed optimization

Note that, since we have α​m𝛼𝑚\alpha m Byzantine machines and since we cannot control the clustering of Byzantine machines, the clustering results of this section are not perfect. We let the third phase of the algorithm, i.e., the robust distributed optimization to take care of this.

In the third stage of our algorithm, we implement robust distributed optimization algorithms to learn models for every cluster. After the robust clustering step, we obtain the clustering results 𝒞^1,𝒞^2,…,𝒞^Ksubscript^𝒞1subscript^𝒞2…subscript^𝒞𝐾\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{1},\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{2},\ldots,\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{K}. In the adversarial setting, the clustering result is not guaranteed to be perfect. Without loss of generality, we assume that more than half of the worker machines in 𝒞^ksubscript^𝒞𝑘\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{k} are from true cluster 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k} for every k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]. We denote the fraction of worker machines in 𝒞^ksubscript^𝒞𝑘\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{k} that do not belong to 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k} by α^ksubscript^𝛼𝑘\hat{\alpha}_{k} and maxk∈[K]⁡α^k<0.5subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾subscript^𝛼𝑘0.5\max_{k\in[K]}\hat{\alpha}_{k}<0.5. The goal of this stage of the algorithm is to learn a model for every cluster, by jointly using all the machines in 𝒞^ksubscript^𝒞𝑘\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{k}.

To do this, we use the recently developed Byzantine-robust distributed learning algorithms. These algorithms usually take the following steps: in every iteration, the master machine sends the model parameter to the worker machines; the worker machines compute the gradient of their loss functions with respect to the model parameter; the master machine conducts a robust estimation of the gradients collected from all the worker machines and run a gradient descent step. Here, the robust estimation of gradients is a subroutine of the algorithm, and there are a few choices that we can consider. Some examples are median, trimmed mean, and high dimensional robust estimation algorithms such as iterative filtering. The statistical error rates of robust distributed gradient descent with median and trimmed mean subroutine have been analyzed by [7], and the error rates of the robust distributed gradient descent with iterative filtering has been analyzed by [8]. Without loss of generality, we analyze the k𝑘kth cluster, where k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] and assume M:=|𝒞^k|assign𝑀subscript^𝒞𝑘M:=|\hat{\mathcal{C}}_{k}|.

We will now state the convergence result of trimmed mean and iterative filtering based robust distributed algorithm. Note that, the number of Byzantine nodes in cluster 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k} is at most α​m𝛼𝑚\alpha m, since in the worst case all the Byzantine nodes will be wrongly clustered together in 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k}. Thus, the fraction of Byzantine nodes in this cluster will be at most α^k=α​mMsubscript^𝛼𝑘𝛼𝑚𝑀\hat{\alpha}_{k}=\frac{\alpha m}{M}. Let wTsuperscript𝑤𝑇w^{T} and w0superscript𝑤0w^{0} are the T𝑇T-th iterate and the initial value of the optimization algorithm respectively and w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} is the global minima. We have the following guarantee.

Theorem 7.

[7, 8] Suppose that Assumptions  4, 2 and 3 hold, and α^k≤12−ϵsubscript^𝛼𝑘12italic-ϵ\hat{\alpha}_{k}\leq\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon for some ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0. With constant step-size of 1/L11subscript𝐿11/L_{1} and with probability at least 1−𝒪​(d(1+n​M)d)1𝒪𝑑superscript1𝑛𝑀𝑑1-\mathcal{O}(\frac{d}{(1+nM)^{d}}), after T𝑇T iterations, we have ‖wT−w∗‖≤(1−λFL1+λF)T​‖w0−w∗‖+2λF​Δ′normsuperscript𝑤𝑇superscript𝑤superscript1subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝐿1subscript𝜆𝐹𝑇normsuperscript𝑤0superscript𝑤2subscript𝜆𝐹superscriptΔ′\|w^{T}-w^{*}\|\leq(1-\frac{\lambda_{F}}{L_{1}+\lambda_{F}})^{T}\|w^{0}-w^{*}\|+\frac{2}{\lambda_{F}}\Delta^{\prime}, where, Δ′:=𝒪~​(α^k​dn+dn​M)assignsuperscriptΔ′~𝒪subscript^𝛼𝑘𝑑𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑀\Delta^{\prime}:=\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\hat{\alpha}_{k}d}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{d}{\sqrt{nM}}) for trimmed mean and Δ′:=𝒪~​(α^kn+dn​M)assignsuperscriptΔ′~𝒪subscript^𝛼𝑘𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑀\Delta^{\prime}:=\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\sqrt{\hat{\alpha}_{k}}}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\sqrt{nM}}) for iterative filtering.

Remark 6.

We can relax Assumption 2 and obtain

Fi​(wT)−Fi​(w∗)≤𝒪~​(α^k​dn+dn​M)subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑤𝑇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑤~𝒪subscript^𝛼𝑘𝑑𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑀\displaystyle F_{i}(w^{T})-F_{i}(w^{*})\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\hat{\alpha}_{k}d}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{d}{\sqrt{nM}})

with high probability for the trimmed mean algorithm. Similarly for the iterative filtering, we have

Fi​(wT)−Fi​(w∗)≤𝒪~​(α^kn+dn​M)subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑤𝑇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑤~𝒪subscript^𝛼𝑘𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑀\displaystyle F_{i}(w^{T})-F_{i}(w^{*})\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\sqrt{\hat{\alpha}_{k}}}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\sqrt{nM}})

with high probability.

Remark 7.

By running T≥L1+λFλF​log⁡(λF2​Δ′​‖w0−w∗‖)𝑇subscript𝐿1subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆𝐹2superscriptΔ′normsuperscript𝑤0superscript𝑤T\geq\frac{L_{1}+\lambda_{F}}{\lambda_{F}}\log(\frac{\lambda_{F}}{2\Delta^{\prime}}\|w^{0}-w^{*}\|) parallel iterations, we can obtain a solution wTsuperscript𝑤𝑇w^{T} satisfying ‖wT−w∗‖2≤𝒪​(Δ′)subscriptnormsuperscript𝑤𝑇superscript𝑤2𝒪superscriptΔ′\|w^{T}-w^{*}\|_{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(\Delta^{\prime}). Also, as shown by [8] the term dn​M𝑑𝑛𝑀\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\sqrt{nM}} is unavoidable, and hence the error rate for iterative trimmed means is order optimal in dimension.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2

The proof of the theorem comes directly via combining Theorem 4 and 7. Let α~i=(ϱ​Mi+α​mMi+α​m)subscript~𝛼𝑖italic-ϱsubscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼𝑚\tilde{\alpha}_{i}=\left(\frac{\varrho M_{i}+\alpha m}{M_{i}+\alpha m}\right). Note that, since GSsubscript𝐺𝑆G_{S} denotes fraction of non-Byzantine machines that are mis-clustered, α~isubscript~𝛼𝑖\tilde{\alpha}_{i} denotes the worst case fraction of Byzantine machines for i𝑖i-th cluster. Assuming maxi∈[K]⁡α~i<12subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝐾subscript~𝛼𝑖12\max_{i\in[K]}\tilde{\alpha}_{i}<\frac{1}{2} and invoking Theorem 7 yields the result.

Appendix D Technical lemmas

We now list a few technical lemmas. These lemmas (along with the proofs) appear in the Appendix of [45], and typically follow from the concentration phenomenon of sub-gaussian random variables. For the sake of completeness of the arguments made in the proofs of Theorem 3 and 4, we are re-writing the results here without proofs.

In the setup of Section 5.1, suppose we have τ1,…,τtsubscript𝜏1…subscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{1},\ldots,\tau_{t} such that τi∼𝒩​(0,σ2​Id)similar-tosubscript𝜏𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscript𝐼𝑑\tau_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}I_{d}) for all i∈[t]𝑖delimited-[]𝑡i\in[t] and τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}’s are independent.

Lemma 4.

Let S⊂[t]𝑆delimited-[]𝑡S\subset[t] with τS=∑i∈Sτisubscript𝜏𝑆subscript𝑖𝑆subscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{S}=\sum_{i\in S}\tau_{i}. We have,

‖τS‖≤σ​2​(n+9​d)​|S|normsubscript𝜏𝑆𝜎2𝑛9𝑑𝑆\|\tau_{S}\|\leq\sigma\sqrt{2(n+9d)|S|}

with probability at least 1−exp⁡(−0.1​t)10.1𝑡1-\exp(-0.1t).

Lemma 5.

Let τ¯=1t​∑i=1tτi¯𝜏1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖\bar{\tau}=\frac{1}{t}\sum_{i=1}^{t}\tau_{i}. We have, ⟨τ¯,θ∗⟩≥−‖θ∗‖2t¯𝜏superscript𝜃superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃2𝑡\langle\bar{\tau},\theta^{*}\rangle\geq-\frac{\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{\sqrt{t}} and ‖τ¯‖2≤3​d​σ2t+‖θ∗‖2tsuperscriptnorm¯𝜏23𝑑superscript𝜎2𝑡superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃2𝑡\|\bar{\tau}\|^{2}\leq\frac{3d\sigma^{2}}{t}+\frac{\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{t} with probability at least 1−2​exp⁡(−‖θ∗‖23​σ2)12superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃23superscript𝜎21-2\exp(-\frac{\|\theta^{*}\|^{2}}{3\sigma^{2}})
